ygData.subject: Re: [neat] Extinction Event
ygData.msgSnippet: ... I don t think it s the same. In nature extinctions occur at a steady rate anyhow, and this is like our species getting old and dieing. A mass extinction

John Arrowwood wrote:

>Isn't that more or less the purpose of the age penalty for species
>that haven't made progress in N generations?
>  
>
I don't think it's the same. In nature extinctions occur at a steady 
rate anyhow, and this is like our species getting old and dieing. A mass 
extinction event disrupts the balance that naturally exist between 
species and perturbs the whole system. This in turns creates new 
opportunities for lifeforms that previously were in some evolutionary 
niche. E.g. mammals are though to have evolved from a slug like 
creature, but this creature probably didn't get an opportunity to 
multiply and flourish until it's predators had been made extinct. So 
while new predators are evolving there is a bit of a window of opportunity.

Hmm, on the other hand there are no reltionships between our species, 
e.g. one species does not eat another allowing population levels to 
balance out. So all we are left with is large gaps in the search space 
that remaining species can spread or explore into. That *is* similar to 
our existing species culling technique, it's just a more 
disruptive/dramatic form of culling.

Getting back to the idea that a change in environment (I don't know, say 
more acidic sea, less predators, etc) creates new areas for species to 
explore, this is equivalent to us modifying the fitness landscape. This 
brings me to a couple of ideas:

1) Firstly my idea of fencing off areas of the search space where past 
species had explored and died of old age. This is one form of modifying 
the fitness space. But this is a way of avoiding where you've already 
been and doesn't fit in with the idea of extinction events to well.

2) Changing the fitness function. We choose a function based on the 
problem at hand, so it doesn't seem sensible to switch to a different 
function. But often we come up with different ways of evaluating netwoks 
for a given problem and we often have discussions about what is the best 
function. What if we were to code up a few of theses different functions 
and allow NEAT to periodically switch between them. This then could be 
something akin to an extinction event occuring in nature and changing 
the fitness landscape.

Colin
